Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Quenchers in advanced oxidation technologies for analysis of micropollutants by liquid chromatography coupled to mass spectrometry: Sodium sulphite or catalase?

AbstractText: This work aimed to investigate the possible effect of 2 quenchers commonly used in H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>-based advanced oxidation technologies (AOTs), i.e. catalase and sodium sulphite (Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>), on the analytical signal of 3 detectors coupled to liquid chromatography (LC): tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS), fluorescence detection (LC-FD) and LC-diode array detection (LC-DAD). The observation of analytical interferences for a group of compounds when studying the removal by continuous mode UV/H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> of 26 micropollutants (MPs) from a spiked surface water (SW), for which the residual H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> in the samples was quenched by Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>, triggered the need of understanding these effects and thus catalase was used as comparative quencher. From the 26 MPs having a wide range of polarity and pK<sub>a</sub>, those monitored after electrospray ionization (ESI) under positive ionization (PI) mode and presenting a pK<sub>a</sub> higher than 5.9 revealed a great signal suppression, but only when using Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub> as H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> quencher. In this sense, we further explored this effect by selecting 2 MPs, metoprolol and diclofenac, which had respectively signal suppression and no interference in the LC-MS/MS response. These MPs were analysed before and after addition of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> and catalase or Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub> in reaction vials, using: (i) different detectors coupled to LC, namely LC-MS/MS with ESI under PI and negative ionization (NI) modes, LC-FD and LC-DAD; (ii) different environmental matrices (SW, drinking water, wastewater) and ultrapure water; and (iii) different magnitude levels (0.1-10 mg L<sup>-1</sup>). The results demonstrated a remarkable signal suppression in LC-MS/MS analyses under PI mode for those compounds with pK<sub>a</sub> higher than 5.9, confirming the interfering effect of H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub>/Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub>. To the best of our knowledge, the analytical interference in the LC-MS/MS analysis, after adding Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub> to quench H<sub>2</sub>O<sub>2</sub> in AOTs experiments was never reported before and the results presented herein support the recommendation to use catalase instead of Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>3</sub> as quencher in AOTs studies.
